function MDXContent(props = {}) {
  const {wrapper: MDXLayout} = props.components || ({});
  return MDXLayout ? _jsx(MDXLayout, Object.assign({}, props, {
    children: _jsx(_createMdxContent, props)
  })) : _createMdxContent(props);
}

You will first learn about the theory behind the algorithm and then see a demonstration of its execution on a QPU.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":["Across disciplines, we're interested in learning ground state properties of quantum systems. Examples include understanding the fundamental nature of particles and forces, predicting and understanding the behavior of complex materials and understanding bio-chemical interactions and reactions. Because of the exponential growth of the Hilbert space and the correlation that arise in entangled systems, classical algorithm struggle to solve this problem for quantum systems of increasing size. At one end of the spectrum is the existing approach that takes advantage of the quantum hardware focus on variational quantum methods (for example, ",["$","$L18",null,{"href":"/docs/tutorials/spin-chain-vqe","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","children":"variational quantum eigensolver"}],"). These techniques face challenges with current devices because of the high number of function calls required in the optimization process, which adds a large overhead in resources once advanced error mitigation techniques are introduced, thus limiting their efficacy to small systems. At the other end of the spectrum, there are fault-tolerant quantum methods with performance guarantees (for example, ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0604193","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["quantum phase estimation",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":[["$","path",null,{"d":"M10 6L10 8 22.59 8 6 24.59 7.41 26 24 9.41 24 22 26 22 26 6 10 6z"}],"$undefined"]}]]}],"), which require deep circuits that can be executed only on a fault-tolerant device. For these reasons, we introduce here a quantum algorithm based on subspace methods (as described in this ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://arxiv.org/abs/2312.00178","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["review paper",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$19","$undefined"]}]]}],"), the Krylov quantum diagonalization (KQD) algorithm. This algorithm performs well at large scale ",["$","a",null,{"href":"#references","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","children":"[1]"}]," on existing quantum hardware, shares similar ",["$","a",null,{"href":"https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.07492","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline","target":"_blank","rel":"noopener nofollow noreferrer","children":["performance guarantees",["$","svg",null,{"focusable":"false","preserveAspectRatio":"xMidYMid meet","fill":"currentColor","aria-label":"(opens in a new tab)","width":16,"height":16,"viewBox":"0 0 32 32","role":"img","className":"inline ml-2","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","children":["$19","$undefined"]}]]}]," as phase estimation, is compatible with advanced error mitigation techniques, and could provide results that are classically inaccessible."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",[["$","hr",null,{"className":"mt-48 lg:mt-64 mb-16 md:mb-24 my-16 lg:my-24 border-t border-border-subtle box-content overflow-visible"}],["$","h2",null,{"id":"requirements","className":"group relative mx-0 scroll-pt-[var(--shell-top-bar-height)] [overflow-wrap:anywhere] text-heading-04 text-text-primary","children":["Requirements",["$","a",null,{"title":"Permalink to this headline","href":"#requirements","className":"text-link-primary no-underline hover:underline inline Repeating several times a certain order Trotter decomposition gives us further reduction of the error introduced from the approximation. In the following, we directly build the Trotter implementation in the most efficient way for the interaction graph of the Hamiltonian we are considering (nearest neighbor interactions only). in the sum, and the second step follows because the sum in the numerator is a subset of the sum in the denominator.
